Authors:
Lisa A Beirn, Lane P Tredway, Michael J Boehm, Angela M
Orshinsky, Alexander I Putman, Ignazio Carbone, Bruce B Clarke, Jo Anne
Crouch
Title:
Clarireedia, a new fungal genus typified by the causal agent
of turfgrass dollar spot disease, Clarireedia homoeocarpa nov.
comb.
Keywords:
Ascomycota, fungarium specimens, Leotiomycetes, molecular
phylogenetics, Rutstroemia, Sclerotinia
Abstract:
Dollar spot is one of the most destructive and
economically debilitating fungal diseases of amenity turfgrasses. The
causal agent was first described in 1937 as the ascomycete Sclerotinia
homoeocarpa. However, the genus-level taxonomic placement of this fungus
has been the subject of ongoing debate for over 75 years. Existing
morphological and rDNA sequence evidence indicates that this organism is
more appropriately placed in the Rutstroemiaceae family rather than the
Sclerotiniaceae. Here we use DNA sequence data from samples of the
dollar spot fungus and other members of the Rutstroemiaceae
(e.g. Poculum, Rutstroemia, Lanzia, Lambertella) from cultured isolates
and fungarium specimens to determine the generic identity of the
turfgrass dollar spot fungus. Phylogenetic evidence from eight
nucleotide sequence markers (actin, β-tubulin, calmodulin, EF-1α, Mcm7,
ITS, LSU, SSU; 3593-bp) confirmed that S. homoeocarpa is not a species
of Sclerotinia; nor is it a member of any known genus in the
Rutstroemiaceae. These data, in combination with morphological
assessments, supported the establishment a new genus, which we describe
as Clarireedia gen. nov. Clarireedia homoeocarpa nov. comb., the type
species for the genus, is described to accommodate the dollar spot
fungus, and a lectotype and epitype are designated. The resolved
taxonomy that accurately reflects this fungus’ identity not only
represents a major step for proper communication by
pathologists/agronomists, but will provide the foundation for
understanding the nature and biology of this destructive pathogen.
